items.content_html:
This PR came out of the work to define page types for HTML (#22705).
From that work we have just three HTML page types:

  • html-element
  • html-attribute
  • html-attribute-value

But we have https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Link_types which AFAICT duplicates the page for rel: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/rel. So this PR attempts to de-dupe them, and standardise on https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/rel, which is more clearly an attribute page in a relatively sensible place.

In this PR I haven't tried to make our docs for rel as good as they possibly could be: I've just tried to avoid the duplication and rationalize what we have and where it is.

  1. 8c4d3a0: improve the rel page, a bit, both from the spec and incorporating a few things from the "link types" page. The idea here is to make sure the rel page is at least as useful as the "link types" page, in preparation for deleting the latter.
  2. d98a770: move "link types" subpages under rel. These pages look a lot like html-attribute-value pages, and pages of this type should probably live underneath their attribute.
  3. 5d3b7e2: retitle rel value pages. We don't have a defined title for html-attribute-value pages, but attribute=value didn't seem too bad for now.
  4. 1346c9d: delete the link types page and redirect to rel.
  5. 2d6e435: update all the places I could find that we were linking to the link types page.
items.title: De-dupe rel attribute page

items.content_html:
substr is deprecated, and in this instance I think substr should be replaceable with substring. Can you verify that this is true? https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/substring#the_difference_between_substring_and_substr

When developers cut and paste this code, then substr is flagged as an issue in the ide that will take needless time to verify.

Description

Motivation

items.content_html:
Description

Any tabindex value suffices for an element to be focusable and thus emit keyboard events. The documentation implies that only tabindex value -1 can do that.

The page in question: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/keydown_event

Motivation

The phrase to be improved suggests that keyboard events are not emitted when the tabindex attribute of the emitting element has value other than -1. In reality, based on MDN, WHATWG, and SO, any tabindex value makes the element focusable. All focusable elements receive keyboard events, see w3c keyboard event order. To be sure, I tested that this is the case with Firefox 74 and Chrome 108.

However, the tab key and keyboard events are in temporal conflict. The tabindex value 0 and above make the element reachable by pressing the tab key. The special tabindex value -1 means that the element cannot be navigated to by pressing the tab key. The keyboard events are emitted when a key is pressed, including the tab key. Thus pressing a tab key either a) emits a keyboard event without changing focus, b) changes focus without emitting the keyboard event, or c) emits the keyboard event and then changes focus. It is unclear which of these happens. Therefore the tabindex value -1 has a special ability to avoid the conflict by not allowing tabbing to reach the keyboard target element. This conflict might have motivated the original author to limit the value to -1.

W3C keyboard event order docs mention this conflict by stating "The event target might change between different key events. For example, a keydown event for the Tab key will likely have a different event target than the keyup event on the same keystroke." This implies that the W3C recommendation is the c) outcome: emit keyboard event and then switch focus.

All in all, any tabindex value will do for element to emit keydown.

Additional details

MDN tabindex
WHATWG tabindex attribute
W3C keyboard event order
items.title: Relax tabindex value

items.content_html:
I've added an impressive web technology demo to the list. It is a 3D mobile web build of Subway Surfers (2B+ downloads in the app store). It is created with Pixi.js and WebGL and runs well on a wide range of lower tier mobile phones.

Created a new link entry plus description

It is the first top 3D titles I've seen that works really well in the mobile web browser.

No related resources
items.title: Add a link to another 3rd-party site to the “Game development » Examples” page

items.content_html:
Description

Images on this page about the element don't work as intended when using dark mode. You cannot see the black edges & borders, which are quite relevant.

I added some white padding around them.

Motivation

Lines & borders of these images where invisible in dark mode.

Additional details

I also made all images of equal size for visual appearance.
items.title: Add whitespace around images, to make black edges visible in dark mode.

items.content_html:
Description

Update the general description for the <b> element.

The last sentence I included is extra information, and could probably be omitted (and may not even be correct if I am misunderstanding the application of the deprecated Boldface element).

Motivation

The existing description is worded somewhat confusingly, and leaves some use cases implied, plus the "instead" clause as written appears to only refer to styling but is meant to refer to styling and importance.

This rewritten description is more clear without being significantly more wordy.
items.title: Update the description for `<b>`
